awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A device to predict the production efficiency of oil crop seeds
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technologies capable of increasing the crop yield and growth efficiency of certain high-value commodity crops. By capitalizing on the high price of arable land and the inherent inefficiencies in producing certain strains of crops at the genetic level, this technology enables farmers to produce larger volumes of valuable foodstuffs by optimizing the quality of the materials they plant. Markedly increasing the production efficiency of certain crops, such as corn, avocados, and peanuts, increases the sellable volume of these products, and their derivatives, including high value edible oils, edible matter, and biomass for biofuel conversion. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of biological toolkits that enable agriculturalists to selectively screen planting materials for qualities that are most compatible with the environment in which they are grown. Crucial to this technology is the development of accurate and fast-acting tools for the identification of pertinent genetic features that dictate crop-environment compatibility. Such features include drought resistance, diseases resistance, pest-resilience, crop height, and future crop yield. Research into the roles that individual and/or groups of genes play in the manifestation of these macroscopic traits has enabled the development of plant-specific assays identifying those qualities most relevant for the productive cultivation of crops and produce. Efficacy testing has proven promising in the lab and plans to expand to larger field trials are on the horizon.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This grant sought to walk through the process of establishing product-market fit for a biological assay in the private sector. After conducting more than 200+ customer discovery interviews with stakeholders in a variety of fields, including the biomolecular, private agriculture, community agriculture, and academic sectors, qualitative interview findings were pooled and analyzed to identify issues commonly experienced by community members across the field. Laboratory technicians and management staff proved to be both most likely and best suited to respond to questions regarding the need for and the added value of new biological assays to existing biological workflows. Additionally, key opinion leaders, procurement leads, field managers, lab managers, agricultural specialists, lab scientists, and contractors were also surveyed to more completely understand this space.

 

Upon reviewing the results of those analyses, prototypes of various biological assays that satisfied the needs of those individuals were conceptualized, sketched out, and proposed. Subsequent presentations of these concepts to key opinion leaders proved promising, garnering support and enthusiasm from the customer segment of interest. In the end, it was concluded that the team was successful in its efforts to demonstrate product-market fit of the biological technologies proposed.

 

As this grant does not support the development of specific technologies, the team is actively working to procure follow-on/seed funding to support development and characterization of this technology. In following with previously documented trends, procuring funding after initial stakeholder engagement and concept funding (a period colloquially referred to as the entrepreneurial “valley of death”) is currently the largest obstacle to moving this technology forward. Despite this lack of funding, the team is actively investigating funding options from private accelerators and incubators. Identifying ways to procure sufficient funding without surrendering significant equity will remain a persistent challenge.”

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2022
Modified by: Michael S Rinkunas
